conversation_id: "681e0820-0b28-8011-9813-616468afff23" title: "Moen Shower Temperature Fix" accounts: ["Account2_exports"] models: [] tags: [] message_count: 137

Moen Shower Temperature Fix

user

system

2025-05-09T13:50:23.618357Z user

{"content_type": "image_asset_pointer", "asset_pointer": "file-service://file-PToTBD7om2njbEZNQFdURA", "size_bytes": 2548818, "width": 1152, "height": 1536, "fovea": null, "metadata": {"dalle": null, "gizmo": null, "generation": null, "container_pixel_height": null, "container_pixel_width": null, "emu_omit_glimpse_image": null, "emu_patches_override": null, "lpe_keep_patch_ijhw": null, "sanitized": true, "asset_pointer_link": null, "watermarked_asset_pointer": null}} This image is a Moen shower knob and Im not sure what type but Im unfamiliar with plumbing beyond just drain lines on an hvac system so do you think you can help me figure out how to fix the issue were having with it?

The issue is that when I turn on the water to hot it only gets lukewarm at best and very slowly (15+minutes) gets a bit hotter but never actually hot. Also if turned all the way to H it reduces the water pressure so that its barely hot enough for a decent shower.

Turning it back just a bit raises the water pressure but the temperature then gets colder.

Im thinking that some sort of a mechanism inside is what regulates the hot/cold mix to keep from burning oneself and it appears to be either malfunctioning or isnt set right.

This is the only faucet in the house here (its in the spare bathroom) that doesnt get hot while the rest will indeed get too hot to handle, even the sink in this bathroom gets hot fairly quickly. It also is the only one with water pressure issues.

Think you could guide me through fixing it?

2025-05-09T13:50:26.156500Z assistant

Absolutely, I can help you with this. Based on your photo and the behavior you're describing, you're dealing with a Moen Posi-Temp valve a common single-handle shower valve that includes a built-in temperature limit stop (also called a scald guard or anti-scald limiter).

Your Problem

  • The water never gets truly hot.
  • Full hot reduces pressure significantly.
  • The rest of the house has proper hot water.

This strongly suggests one of the following issues:

Most Likely Causes

  1. Temperature Limit Stop Is Set Too Low

    • Moen valves come with a plastic rotational limit stop to prevent scalding. If it's too restricted, it prevents the handle from rotating far enough toward hot.
    • Symptoms: Lukewarm water only, especially if other faucets get hotter.
    • Fix: Remove the handle and adjust the limit stop.

  2. Clogged or Partially Blocked Cartridge

    • If debris or mineral buildup is restricting flow, especially on the hot side, it can both lower pressure and temperature.
    • Symptoms: Weak hot pressure, delayed heating.
    • Fix: Replace or clean the cartridge.

  3. Worn or Faulty Cartridge

    • Over time, the cartridge can wear out or fail internally, which skews the mix.
    • Symptoms: Water never gets hot enough no matter what, low flow on hot only.
    • Fix: Replace the cartridge (usually a Moen 1222 for Posi-Temp).

Step-by-Step: First Try Adjusting the Temperature Limit Stop

Heres how to adjust it:

Tools you might need:

  • Phillips screwdriver
  • Allen wrench (if handle has a set screw)
  • Flathead screwdriver or needle-nose pliers

Steps:

  1. Turn off water at the shower valve (or main if there's no local shutoff).
  2. Remove the handle:
    • If theres a screw under the handle or behind it, unscrew it with the right tool.
    • Pull the handle off.
  3. Remove the escutcheon (faceplate) if necessary (not always needed).
  4. Locate the limit stop:
    • Its a plastic piece on the cartridge stem or behind the handle.
    • It usually rotates like a gear rotating it counterclockwise (on most models) allows more hot water.
  5. Rotate it one or two notches, then reassemble and test.
  6. Repeat adjustments until you reach the desired temperature.

If That Doesnt Work: Replace the Cartridge

If adjusting the stop doesnt fix the low pressure and temp, youll want to:

  1. Buy a Moen 1222 Posi-Temp Cartridge (confirm your valve model first).
  2. Follow a tutorial to swap it out I can guide you step-by-step if you get to this point.

Would you like to start with adjusting the temperature limit stop and see if that resolves it? If so, I can walk you through with pictures or diagrams if you like.

2025-05-09T13:50:37.903760Z assistant

2025-05-09T13:52:48.694151Z user

Well start with adjusting the limit. Ive looked it up before and positemp sounds like what I remember. I think I failed to find the right Allen key size to get the handle off. So shut the water off first you said?

2025-05-09T13:52:50.009380Z assistant

Great yes, adjusting the limit stop is a smart first move.

Heres the step-by-step breakdown for the Moen Posi-Temp valve:

1. Shut Off the Water (Optional but Recommended)

For just adjusting the limit stop (not replacing the cartridge), you can technically do this with the water still on, if you're careful not to turn the valve on while it's disassembled.
But for safety:

  • Best Practice: Turn off the water only if you're worried about accidentally turning the valve while working.
  • If you feel confident not to rotate the stem while it's open, you can leave it on.

2. Remove the Handle

Youll need to:

  • Identify the set screw its usually located:

    • Underneath the handle (look underneath the curved part)
    • Or hidden under a decorative cap on the front

  • Tools:

    • Most Moen handles use a 7/64" hex (Allen) key, sometimes 1/8" or even 3/32"
    • A flashlight helps if its recessed

Steps:

  1. Insert the Allen key and rotate counter-clockwise to loosen.
  2. Pull the handle straight off.
    • If it's stuck due to mineral deposits, a little gentle wiggle or penetrating oil can help.

3. Adjust the Temperature Limit Stop

  • Look for the plastic limiter (white, gray, or beige gear-like piece) around the valve stem.
  • It may look like a half-circle collar with small notches.

How to adjust:

  • Pull it off gently or slide it outward if its on a track.
  • Rotate it counter-clockwise (usually to allow more hot water).
  • Replace it on the new notch.
  • Start with 12 notches, then test.

4. Reassemble & Test

  1. Put the handle back on loosely and test the water temperature.
  2. If its still too cool, remove and rotate the stop further.
  3. Once satisfied, tighten the set screw fully.

If you run into resistance getting the handle off or want me to review an image of the disassembled part once the handle is off, feel free to send a photo. Want me to generate a visual guide to match what youll see behind the handle?

Here's What You're Looking At:

  • That tab on the left side (about 10 o'clock position) is currently blocking the valve from rotating further counterclockwise, which is the direction you'd go to get hotter water.

How to Adjust It (Manually Without Full Removal):

Step-by-Step (Revised):

    • It should be gently liftable or rotatable without tools.

Thanks for these updated images they show everything clearly. Youve done the right thing getting to this point, and I now see exactly whats happening.

Heres What Youre Looking At:

That white plastic ring with the gear teeth underneath the black handle piece that is the temperature limit stop.

The black part thats turning the water on is the actual cartridge stem, so turning that will activate flow. Youre not meant to rotate the black cap itself to adjust the white notched ring is the real limiter.

Here's How to Adjust It (Final Clear Steps):

  1. Pull off the black plastic handle adapter (you're already holding it in the third photo).

    • It may take a gentle tug, no screw or twist needed.
    • Once removed, youll expose the white notched ring fully.

  2. Rotate the white ring clockwise (toward more hot).

    • Each notch you rotate it clockwise (from your view), will allow the handle to rotate further counterclockwise when reassembled, giving you hotter water.

  3. Line it up with a new tooth and push it back in place.

    • Youll feel it click in or sit snug.

  4. Reinstall the black piece and test the handle.

    • If the handle now turns further toward hot, you should get higher temps.
    • You may need to adjust once or twice to get it just right.

Visual Aid (Based on Your Setup):

FRONT VIEW of limit stop:

          Rotate this direction (clockwise) to allow hotter water
     ________
    |        |   
    |        |  <- White gear ring with teeth
    |________|

Lets lock this in clearly:

To Allow More Hot Water:

  • You do need to:
    1. Remove the black adapter (done).
    2. Unscrew the screw holding the white plastic stop (what you're seeing now).
    3. Remove the white limiter ring from the stem.

Now rotate it:

  • Look at the flat edge with the teeth.
  • To allow more hot:
    • Rotate the white ring clockwise when viewed from the front (as you're looking straight at the valve in the shower).
    • You are rotating it in the direction that will let the handle turn further counterclockwise (toward HOT).

Clockwise limiter rotation = handle can turn more counterclockwise = more hot water.

Step-by-Step Recap:

  1. Use a screwdriver to remove the screw holding the white plastic stop.
  2. Lift off the limiter ring.
  3. Rotate it clockwise by 12 teeth.
  4. Reinstall it, screw it back down.
  5. Reassemble the handle and test.

Final Tip:

Each notch increases your temp limit by about 35F. You can fine-tune it after testing by repeating this if needed.

2025-05-09T14:31:56.810783Z user

So even with it taken completely all the way off and out of play (the limit stop) the faucet still doesnt supply hot water and the pressure drops when turn all the way the H side

2025-05-09T14:31:57.956601Z assistant

Ah now thats a critical clue.

If the temperature limit stop is completely removed and:

  • You still dont get truly hot water, and
  • The pressure drops significantly when turned to full hot,

then weve now ruled out the limiter as the issue and you're likely dealing with:

A Failing or Clogged Cartridge (Moen 1222 Posi-Temp)

Heres whats probably happening:

  • The cartridge's internal seals or pressure-balancing spool are sticking or clogged.
  • It restricts hot water flow disproportionately especially under pressure.
  • This is why cold has better pressure, and why even after 15 minutes, the temp doesnt climb much.

Fix: Replace the Cartridge

  • Your current cartridge is almost certainly a Moen 1222 (for Posi-Temp valves).
  • You can:
    • Buy an OEM Moen 1222 cartridge (not a knockoff if possible).
    • Use a cartridge puller tool (optional but highly recommended Moen makes one).
    • Swap out the cartridge and test.

Basic Replacement Steps (once youre ready):

  1. Shut off the water.
  2. Remove the handle and retaining clip.
  3. Pull out the old cartridge (may be stuck a puller helps).
  4. Lube and insert the new one (orientation matters Ill help if needed).
  5. Reassemble and test.

Would you like me to write out the full replacement steps next? I can tailor it to your comfort level and tools on hand.

2025-05-09T14:33:11.981949Z user

So to clarify this does require cutting water off? The replacement of cartridge I mean.

2025-05-09T14:33:12.990691Z assistant

Yes you absolutely must shut off the water before replacing the cartridge.

Unlike just adjusting the limiter, removing the cartridge opens the valve body directly to your water supply, and if the water isn't off:

  • You'll get a blast of pressurized water straight out of the wall (hot and cold).
  • You could also damage the valve housing or injure yourself.

So yes to be clear:

Cartridge replacement = shut off the water first.

  • If theres no local shutoff valve near the shower, youll need to:
    • Shut off the main water supply to the house.
    • Then open a faucet elsewhere to drain pressure from the lines.

Let me know if youd like the full step-by-step for the cartridge swap, or a checklist of what to have on hand before starting.

2025-05-09T15:10:41.988855Z assistant

Yes that experience absolutely counts and heres why:

Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) are just industrial-grade computers used to control electromechanical processes and while you may not have programmed one directly, working with thermostats and VFDs (Variable Frequency Drives) on Liebert systems means youve interacted with:

  • Microprocessor-based control systems (like what PLCs manage)
  • Sensor feedback loops
  • Relay-controlled outputs
  • System alarms, setpoints, and sometimes BACnet or Modbus protocols

So how should you phrase it?

You can say:

"While I havent directly programmed PLCs, I do have experience working with microprocessor-based control systems and VFD controllers on commercial Liebert HVAC systems. Ive configured setpoints, diagnosed faults, and managed system integration through onboard interfaces which operate similarly to PLC logic."

Thats honest, accurate, and shows youre not starting from scratch.

The Moen 1222 Posi-Temp cartridge usually runs around:

  • $10$20 USD for off-brand or aftermarket versions (not always reliable)

You can find it at:

  • Home Depot / Lowes: ~$25

  • Local plumbing supply stores: often similar in price, sometimes bundled with cartridge pullers

2025-05-09T17:59:21.512098Z assistant

I can guide you through uploading it to R2 using rclone, wrangler, or a direct API call but I cant push to R2 myself due to system restrictions.

If youre ready to do it manually later, heres a quick upload cheat sheet for Cloudflare R2 using rclone:

Upload to R2 via rclone

1. Configure rclone

Run:

rclone config

And add a new remote with:

  • Storage: s3
  • Provider: Cloudflare
  • Access Key / Secret: From your R2 dashboard
  • Endpoint: https://<account_id>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com

2. Upload the File

2025-05-09T19:19:00.779271Z assistant

Based on your request and the full mythos of The Nightfall Series especially the ancient tone, symbolic echoes of The Book, the role of Eric as The Key, and the interplay of shadow, fate, and remembrance here is a poetic, mythos-styled entry you could embed as an ancient excerpt from The Book, perhaps discovered midway through a sequel or referenced in whispered tones by one of the Preori or the Nastaku themselves.

The Song of the Lost Key

(from the Scrolls of Htrae, Book IV: Echoes Before the First Sound)

They played a game before the world began,  
And for each loss, they gave a gift:  
A seed, a star, a coin, a man  
In scattered vessels, power split.  

A dagger, book, a woman, tree  
Each holding fragments none could see.  
But one among them bore the flame,  
The one for whom none spoke a name.  

For he was not a wielder born,  
Nor forged by rage, nor crowned with thorn  
But walked in love where swords would clash,  
A silent light, no thunder's flash.  

And so the dark sought him unseen,  
In every realm, behind the screen.  
They wrote his fate in twisted code,  
And sent their dogs upon the road.  

They bent the game, rewrote the rules,  
Made gods of fear and kings of fools.  
Yet still he walked, unknown, unheard  
The quiet echo of the Word.  

His name was lost in shattered scrolls,  
His love dismissed by louder roles.  
The war grew loud, the winds turned dire  
And still he carried sacred fire.  

He loved a child that was not his,  
And gave the world a second wish.  
He bore the weight that none could hold,  
The Key to stories left untold.  

The warriors blade would soon run red,  
But not before the Key had bled.  
And through that pain, a gate was opened  
Not by might, but love unbroken.  

They say he walks still in the strands,  
Between the pages, past all lands.  
The game continues, dark and steep  
But he alone still guards the leap.  

So mark the ones who seem unseen,  
Whose hearts hold truth beyond the screen.  
And when the stars forget to gleam  
Remember:  
He is the dream within the dream.

This poem can stand as a forgotten hymn from The Book, whose language speaks directly to both the mythos and your lived journey. It can be cited by Finneas or echoed in a dream Brian or Eric experiences in future volumes. And it can also be used in the Lost Was the Key album either as a lyrical interlude or the final tracks spoken-word invocation.

Let me know if you'd like it formatted into parchment-styled visual, embedded into a mock page from "The Book," or adapted musically. This is the heart of your myth, remembered.
